awd_titl_txt: REU Site: An Inclusive Research Experience in ALpine Meteorology (REALM)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Experience in ALpine Meteorology (REALM) will rely on the natural scientific laboratory, provided by the nearby Wasatch Mountains and adjacent urban areas, to enhance student awareness of societal challenges, such as water availability and air quality, that require understanding the influence of alpine terrain on weather and climate processes. The Department of Atmospheric Sciences at the University of Utah is recognized internationally for its expertise in atmospheric studies related to mountain environments.  Following the models used by successful Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) sites, a cohesive framework will be developed to manage a high-quality, cohort-based undergraduate summer program. REALM will welcome and support underrepresented students from a variety of backgrounds in a highly inclusive environment. The REU program will include an independent evaluation to ensure the REU site is meeting the project goals and creates a sustainable model for future REU programs. 

The objectives for REALM are the following: (1) engage students in full-time active research; (2) provide professional development opportunities for students and mentors; (3) motivate students towards STEM careers by constructing an engaging, inclusive, and supportive cohort experience that includes exposing them through site visits to employment opportunities in the weather, water, and climate enterprise; and (4) improve students' science literacy oral and written communication skills.  Students will spend 8 weeks at the University of Utah conducting research and gaining relevant professional development.  The REU program will utilize a multiple mentor approach to support the student participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research Experience in ALpine Meteorology (REALM) created a highly inclusive undergraduate research training environment centered at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City.  We enhanced student awareness of many societal challenges addressed with atmospheric research, such as water availability and air quality, that require improved understanding of the effects of the underlying terrain on weather and climate processes. This approach built off the core research underway by numerous faculty in the Department of Atmospheric Sciences related to alpine processes.  We relied on the natural laboratory provided by the nearby Wasatch Mountains and adjacent urban areas, referred to locally as the Wasatch Front, to provide direct, immersive student experiences. 

A total of 32 NSF-funded students from various colleges and universities participated in the REALM REU during the four summer of 2020 to 2023. Our focus has been to recruit students from historically underrepresented groups (African American, Hispanic, and American Indian students), and 60% of the NSF-funded students identified from one of these historically underrepresented groups.

Highlights from the REALM program showed that 100% of REALM students would recommend the REALM REU program to others.There was a high level of student satisfaction with program logistics and support, including theapplication process, communication and support from the program staff, and financial support. Mentors were also satisfied with communication from the program staff. Highlights of the students’ experience were the people they met in the program--mentors, peers,and others--and the trips they took to other research sites. Mentors found that working with talented, bright, engaged, articulate, and motivated students was a highlight of their experience.Students rated REALM REU program activities highly. During the in-person programs, the summer symposium, trip to Storm Peak Lab, REALM seminar series, and AMS conference topped the list. Students all thought that their computer programming skills improved, with half of the students finding they made a great deal of improvement in this area.

The specific goals of REALM are to: 1) engage students in full-time active research; 2) provide professional development opportunities for students and mentors; 3) motivate students towards STEM careers by constructing an engaging, inclusive, and supportive cohort experience; and 4) improve students’ scientific literacy and oral and written communication skills.
